text:
CLARE SEBASTIAN: At
Kremlin-funded TV channel, RT,

the issue of fake
news is personal.

ANDREW KIYASHKO: A lot of
people are saying, well,
this is ironic.
RT is doing Fake Check.
Well, we don't think so.

CLARE SEBASTIAN: Fake
Check is a new project

by RT, a slick,
interactive website that it

says aims to expose
false or misleading
elements in news stories.

ANDREW KIYASHKO: We're not
labeling anyone as fake.

We're just saying,
well probably,

you could question
this a little bit.

CLARE SEBASTIAN: The
story selected though,
including-- and now corrected--

Washington Post article
which initially cited

federal authorities,
suggesting Russian hackers

penetrated the US electricity
grid points to a Russia
that is fighting back.

ANDREW KIYASHKO:
This whole story

about the Russian
hacking, for example--

I mean, this is
being positioning
by a lot of media as a fact.

Although as we know, the report
by the intelligence community
did not have a certainty.

It had a certain degree
of certainly, not fact.

So that's why we do think that
Russia is being victimized.

CLARE SEBASTIAN: And it's not
just state-controlled media
that feels that way.

Russia's foreign ministry
says fake news about Russia

is becoming almost
a daily occurrence
and it's taking action.

Last month, the Ministry
unveiled a new section

of its website
dedicated to debunking
what it calls fake reports.

So far, the New York Times,
Bloomberg, Al Jazeera, and CNN

are among those
given the ministry's
fake stamp on real news.
The claim against CNN--

a report citing current and
former senior US government

officials that Russian
ambassador to the US,

Sergey Kislyak, is quote,
"considered by the US

to be one of Russia's top
spies and spy recruiters
in Washington."

Russia's Foreign Ministry
Spokesman had this response
to CNN's Matthew Change.

MARIA ZAKHAROVA: Stop
spreading lies and false news.
You This is good advice for CNN.

CLARE SEBASTIAN: Konstantin von
Eggert, an anchor for TV Rain,

a rare independent
Russian TV channel,

says Russia is simply
turning defense into offense.

KONSTANTIN VON EGGERT: I think
that accusations of fake news

spread by Moscow have
become so common in the West

that finally, a decision
was taken to a somehow react
to that.

CLARE SEBASTIAN: So
while Russia may still

be waiting for a new friendship
with US President Trump,

it seems they have at least
found a common target.

DONALD TRUMP: It's
all fake news.
It's all fake news.

MARIA ZAKHAROVA: Please stop
spreading lies and false news.

CLARE SEBASTIAN: Clare
Sebastian, CNN, Moscow.
